prompt: A bar chart shows the number of students in each major: Business (45), Engineering (38), Arts (22), Science (31). Which type of graph is most appropriate for this data?
solutionSteps: The data shows categories (majors) and their counts
Bar charts are used for categorical data with gaps between bars
Histograms are for quantitative data with continuous bins

prompt: A Pareto chart displays customer complaint types. What distinguishes a Pareto chart from a regular bar chart?
choices: Bars are arranged in descending order of frequency
Bars are arranged in ascending order
Bars have no gaps between them
correctAnswer: Bars are arranged in descending order of frequency
solutionSteps: Pareto charts follow the Pareto principle (80/20 rule)
Categories are ordered from most frequent to least frequent
This helps identify the most important categories
Often includes a cumulative percentage line

prompt: Which graph would be most appropriate to display how a company's stock price changed over the past year?
solutionSteps: Time is the independent variable on the x-axis
Time-series graphs show trends and patterns over time
The y-axis shows the value being measured (price)

prompt: A histogram shows test scores: 60-70 (5 students), 70-80 (12 students), 80-90 (18 students), 90-100 (8 students). What is the class width?
solutionSteps: Class width = Upper limit - Lower limit of any class
All classes have the same width in a histogram

prompt: In a boxplot, the box represents what portion of the data?
solutionSteps: The box extends from Q1 to Q3
Q1 is the 25th percentile, Q3 is the 75th percentile
The range Q1 to Q3 contains the middle 50% of data
This range is called the Interquartile Range (IQR)

prompt: A boxplot shows: Min=12, Q1=25, Median=35, Q3=48, Max=72, with a point at 85. What does the point at 85 represent?
solutionSteps: Individual points beyond the whiskers represent outliers

prompt: What is the main difference between a histogram and a bar chart?
choices: Bar charts are for quantitative data
Histograms have no gaps and show quantitative data
Bar charts must be in order
correctAnswer: Histograms have no gaps and show quantitative data
solutionSteps: Bars in histograms touch because data is continuous
Bars in bar charts have gaps to show distinct categories

prompt: Looking at a histogram, how can you estimate the median?
choices: Find the class that contains the middle observation
Calculate the mean of all bar heights
correctAnswer: Find the class that contains the middle observation
solutionSteps: Count frequencies from left until you reach or pass this position
The median falls in that class

prompt: A time-series graph of monthly sales shows a clear upward pattern with regular peaks in December. What two features are being displayed?
solutionSteps: Seasonality: Regular patterns that repeat at fixed intervals
December peaks suggest holiday shopping patterns
Both components are common in business time-series data

prompt: In a boxplot, the whiskers extend to:
choices: The minimum and maximum values always
1.5 × IQR from the quartiles, or to the most extreme non-outlier
correctAnswer: 1.5 × IQR from the quartiles, or to the most extreme non-outlier
solutionSteps: Whiskers extend to the fences OR the most extreme data point within the fences
Points beyond fences are marked as individual outliers

prompt: A histogram of ages at a retirement community would most likely be:
solutionSteps: Retirement communities have a minimum age requirement
Most residents cluster at older ages
Fewer residents at younger ages (just meeting minimum)
The tail extends to the left (younger ages) = skewed left

prompt: What type of graph should NOT be used to compare values across categories?
solutionSteps: Bar charts compare category values directly
Pareto charts compare values in decreasing order
Pie charts compare parts to the whole
All three work for categorical comparisons, though bar charts are often clearest

prompt: A histogram has the following frequencies: 3, 8, 15, 22, 18, 10, 4. What is the approximate shape?
solutionSteps: Frequencies increase to a peak (22) in the middle
This bell-shaped pattern suggests symmetric/normal distribution

prompt: In a boxplot, which value is always shown inside the box?
solutionSteps: The box shows Q1, median (Q2), and Q3
The median is marked by a line inside the box
The mean may or may not be shown (sometimes as a point)
The median divides the box into two parts

prompt: A frequency polygon is created by connecting the midpoints of the tops of histogram bars. When is this useful?
choices: When comparing two or more distributions
When the sample size is small
correctAnswer: When comparing two or more distributions
solutionSteps: Frequency polygons are lines connecting class midpoints
Multiple overlapping histograms are hard to read
Frequency polygons allow easy comparison of shapes
The area under the curve still represents total frequency

prompt: A distribution has a mean of 45 and a median of 52. What is the likely shape?
solutionSteps: When mean < median, the distribution is skewed left
Left skew has a tail extending to lower values
The mean is pulled toward the tail (lower values)

prompt: Income data for a city shows mean = $85,000 and median = $52,000. What shape is this distribution?
solutionSteps: When mean > median, distribution is skewed right
High income earners pull the mean up
Right skew is common for income data

prompt: For a symmetric distribution, which of the following is true?
solutionSteps: In a symmetric distribution, data is balanced
The mean and median are at the center
They are equal or approximately equal

prompt: A bar chart shows favorite colors: Red (25), Blue (40), Green (18), Yellow (12). Can you determine the shape of this distribution?
solutionSteps: Skewness applies only to quantitative data
The order of categories is arbitrary
Shape cannot be determined for categorical data

prompt: Test scores on a very easy exam would likely produce what shape distribution?
solutionSteps: An easy exam means most students score high
Tail extends to the left = skewed left (negatively skewed)

prompt: House prices in a neighborhood have mean = $320,000 and median = $285,000. For a potential buyer, which measure better represents a 'typical' home?
choices: Mean, because it includes all values
Median, because the distribution is likely skewed
correctAnswer: Median, because the distribution is likely skewed
solutionSteps: A few expensive homes pull the mean up
Median is resistant to extreme values
Median ($285,000) better represents a typical home

prompt: Which measure of spread is most appropriate for a heavily skewed distribution?
solutionSteps: Standard deviation and variance are sensitive to outliers
Range uses only extreme values, easily affected by outliers
IQR uses Q1 and Q3, ignoring extreme values
IQR is resistant/robust for skewed distributions

prompt: A histogram shows most data on the right with a long tail extending left. This is:
solutionSteps: The tail points to the direction of skew
Tail extending left = left skew = negative skew
The peak is on the right side
Positively skewed = right skew = tail pointing right

prompt: For a symmetric distribution, which measures of center and spread are typically reported?
solutionSteps: Symmetric distributions have no significant outliers
Standard deviation describes spread around the mean
These are preferred for symmetric/normal distributions

prompt: The ages of cars in a used car lot would likely have what shape?
solutionSteps: Most used cars are relatively new (1-5 years)
Age has a lower bound of 0
Tail extends to right (older cars) = right skew

prompt: A distribution is described as 'positively skewed.' What does this mean about the tail?
choices: The tail extends to the left
The tail extends to the right
There are two tails of equal length
correctAnswer: The tail extends to the right
solutionSteps: The tail points toward positive values
Most data clusters on the left (lower values)
Mean is pulled right of the median

prompt: If a distribution is skewed right, in what order are the mean, median, and mode typically found?
solutionSteps: In right-skewed distributions, the tail pulls the mean right
Median is between mode and mean

prompt: Waiting times at a popular restaurant would likely show what distribution shape?
solutionSteps: Most waits are short to moderate
Occasional very long waits stretch the tail
Right skew with lower bound at 0

prompt: A distribution where mean ≈ median ≈ mode is most likely:
solutionSteps: When all three measures are equal, the distribution is symmetric
The center of the distribution is clearly defined
This is called a unimodal symmetric distribution

prompt: SAT scores are designed to follow approximately what distribution shape?
solutionSteps: SAT scores are designed to be normally distributed
Most scores cluster around the mean (about 1060)
Scores spread symmetrically above and below

prompt: A frequency table shows: Class 10-19 has frequency 5, Class 20-29 has frequency 12, Class 30-39 has frequency 8. What is the relative frequency of class 20-29?
Given classes 0-9, 10-19, 20-29 with frequencies 4, 7, 9, what is the cumulative frequency for class 20-29?
solutionSteps: Cumulative frequency = sum of all frequencies up to and including that class

prompt: A frequency table has classes 15-24, 25-34, 35-44. What are the class midpoints?
Classes are: 100-119, 120-139, 140-159. What is the class width?
solutionSteps: Class width = difference between consecutive lower limits

prompt:
Calculate the mean from grouped data:
Class 0-10: frequency 3
Class 10-20: frequency 7
Class 20-30: frequency 5
What is the difference between class limits and class boundaries?
choices: Boundaries have 0.5 added/subtracted to eliminate gaps
Limits are always larger than boundaries
Boundaries only apply to categorical data
correctAnswer: Boundaries have 0.5 added/subtracted to eliminate gaps
solutionSteps: Class boundaries: eliminate gaps between classes

prompt: A relative frequency table shows: 0.15, 0.25, 0.35, 0.20 for four classes. What should these sum to?
solutionSteps: They must sum to 1 (or 100% if expressed as percentages)

prompt: Data ranges from 23 to 87. If you want 6 classes, what should the class width be?
solutionSteps: Class width = Range / Number of classes
Round UP to ensure all data fits: 11

prompt: In a cumulative frequency table, the last class should have what cumulative frequency?
solutionSteps: Cumulative frequency adds all frequencies up to each class
The last class includes all data
Its cumulative frequency equals total observations
This equals n, the sample size

prompt: A grouped data set has mean calculated from midpoints. Will this be exactly equal to the true mean?
choices: Only if the distribution is symmetric
Only if all frequencies are equal
solutionSteps: We assume all values in a class equal the midpoint
The calculated mean is an estimate of the true mean

prompt: A frequency table has 5 classes with cumulative frequencies 8, 23, 45, 58, 65. What is the frequency of the third class?
If you have 50 data points and want to use Sturges' rule for the number of classes, how many classes should you use?
Convert to cumulative relative frequency: Class A: 0.20, Class B: 0.35, Class C: 0.45. What is Class B's cumulative relative frequency?
solutionSteps: Cumulative relative frequency adds previous relative frequencies

prompt: Classes 50-59, 60-69, 70-79 have frequencies 12, 18, 10. In which class does the median fall?
solutionSteps: The 20.5th value is in the second class (positions 13-30)

prompt: What is the class midpoint for the class 45-54?
Given Q1 = 25, Q3 = 45, what is the IQR?
Given Q1 = 25, Q3 = 45, IQR = 20, what is the upper fence for outlier detection?
Data: 5, 8, 12, 15, 18, 22, 25, 28, 32, 85. Which value is an outlier?
solutionSteps: First find Q1, Q3, and IQR

prompt: A dataset has outliers. Which measures of center and spread should be used?
solutionSteps: Outliers affect the mean and standard deviation
Median and IQR are resistant to outliers
They give a better representation of typical values
Use median and IQR for skewed data or data with outliers

prompt: A boxplot shows Q1=30, Median=45, Q3=55. The upper whisker extends to 80 and there's a point at 95. Is 95 an outlier?
What percentage of data falls between Q1 and Q3?
solutionSteps: The IQR contains the middle 50% of data

prompt: Data: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16. What is the minimum value in the five-number summary?
solutionSteps: The five-number summary is: Min, Q1, Median, Q3, Max
The minimum value is the first number

prompt: If a value equals the upper fence exactly, is it an outlier?
solutionSteps: Outliers are values BEYOND the fences
A value must be > upper fence or < lower fence
A value AT the fence is the most extreme non-outlier
So no, it's not an outlier

prompt: A symmetric dataset has no outliers. Would mean or median be a better measure of center?
solutionSteps: Convention often favors mean for symmetric data

prompt: Q1=20, Q2=30, Q3=50. Is this distribution symmetric or skewed?
solutionSteps: Q3 is farther from the median than Q1
More spread on the right = skewed right

prompt: Calculate the lower fence: Q1=45, Q3=72, IQR=27
In a boxplot, the left whisker extends to 15, Q1=25, Median=35, Q3=45, right whisker to 60, with a point at 5. What can you conclude?
solutionSteps: The left whisker extends to 15, not 5
5 is plotted as an individual point

prompt: Data: 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20, 22, 24, 26. If we add 100 to each value, how does the IQR change?
solutionSteps: Adding a constant shifts all values equally
Q1 increases by 100, Q3 increases by 100
Spread measures are not affected by adding constants

prompt: What is the relationship between the median and Q2?
solutionSteps: Q2 divides the data in half
This is exactly what the median does

prompt: Using the empirical rule, approximately what percentage of data falls within 2 standard deviations of the mean in a normal distribution?
solutionSteps: The empirical rule (68-95-99.7) applies to normal distributions

prompt: A dataset has μ = 100 and σ = 15. Calculate the z-score for x = 130.
A value has a z-score of -2.5. Is this value unusual?
Heights are normally distributed with μ = 68 inches and σ = 3 inches. What range contains approximately 68% of heights?
If μ = 500 and σ = 100, what is the value corresponding to z = -1.5?
In a normal distribution with μ = 50 and σ = 8, approximately what percentage of values fall below 34?
solutionSteps: z = -2 means 2 standard deviations below mean

prompt: What does a z-score of 0 indicate?
solutionSteps: A z-score of 0 means the value equals the mean

prompt: Test scores are normally distributed with μ = 75 and σ = 10. What percentage of students scored above 95?
solutionSteps: 95 is 2 standard deviations above the mean
By empirical rule, 2.5% is above z = 2

prompt: Which statement about the standard normal distribution is TRUE?
solutionSteps: The standard normal distribution is a special normal distribution
All normal distributions can be converted to it using z-scores

prompt: Data has μ = 200 and σ = 25. Between what values does approximately 99.7% of the data fall?
Student A scored 85 on a test with μ=80, σ=5. Student B scored 90 on a test with μ=82, σ=4. Who performed better relative to their class?
If a z-score is 3.5, approximately what percentage of values are above this?
solutionSteps: z = 3.5 is far in the right tail

prompt: The empirical rule applies to which type of distribution?
solutionSteps: The empirical rule (68-95-99.7) is specific to normal distributions
Normal distributions are symmetric and bell-shaped
The rule doesn't apply to skewed or other distributions
It describes how data spreads in a normal curve

prompt: Birth weights are normally distributed with μ = 7.5 lbs and σ = 1.2 lbs. A baby weighing 4.5 lbs has z-score of:
In a normal distribution, what percentage of data falls between z = -1 and z = 1?
solutionSteps: This is the range within ±1 standard deviation
Which corresponds to z = -1 to z = 1

prompt: In the equation ŷ = 15 + 2.5x, what is the slope?
solutionSteps: The equation is in form ŷ = a + bx
The slope is the coefficient of x

prompt: Using ŷ = 10 + 3x, predict y when x = 5.

choices: 81% of variation in y is explained by x
81% of data points are on the line
correctAnswer: 81% of variation in y is explained by x
solutionSteps: r² is the coefficient of determination
It represents the proportion of variance explained
r² = 0.81 means 81% of variation in y is explained
by the linear relationship with x

prompt: Calculate the residual: predicted y = 45, actual y = 52
A study finds a strong positive correlation between ice cream sales and drowning deaths. Does ice cream cause drowning?
choices: No, correlation does not imply causation
Only if the sample size is large
correctAnswer: No, correlation does not imply causation
solutionSteps: Hot weather increases ice cream sales AND swimming
More swimming leads to more drowning incidents

prompt: In a study of height (x) and weight (y), which is the explanatory variable?
solutionSteps: We use height to predict weight

prompt: A correlation coefficient r = -0.85 indicates:
solutionSteps: The sign indicates direction: negative = inverse relationship
r = -0.85 is a strong negative relationship

prompt: Data ranges from x = 10 to x = 50. Using the regression equation to predict y when x = 75 is called:
solutionSteps: Interpolation: predicting within the data range
Extrapolation: predicting outside the data range
This is extrapolation and may be unreliable

prompt: If r = 0.7, what is r²?
The slope of a regression line is -2.5. This means:
choices: y increases by 2.5 for each unit increase in x
y decreases by 2.5 for each unit increase in x
correctAnswer: y decreases by 2.5 for each unit increase in x
solutionSteps: Slope indicates change in y per unit change in x
Negative slope means y decreases as x increases

prompt: What is the range of possible values for r?
ŷ = 50 - 1.2x. When x = 0, what is ŷ?
A residual plot shows a clear curved pattern. What does this suggest?
choices: The linear model is a good fit
The linear model is not appropriate
correctAnswer: The linear model is not appropriate
solutionSteps: A good residual plot shows random scatter
Patterns indicate the model doesn't fit well
A curved pattern suggests a nonlinear relationship
A different model should be considered

prompt: If r² = 0.64 for a positive relationship, what is r?
What is a lurking variable?
choices: A variable that is measured but not reported
A variable not in the study that affects both x and y
The y-intercept of the regression line
A value with a large residual
correctAnswer: A variable not in the study that affects both x and y
solutionSteps: A lurking variable is hidden (not measured)
It affects both variables being studied

Example: Temperature affecting both ice cream and drowning

prompt: A fair coin is flipped. What is the sample space?
solutionSteps: A coin has two sides: Heads and Tails
Each outcome is equally likely with P = 0.5

prompt: Events A and B are mutually exclusive. P(A) = 0.3, P(B) = 0.4. Find P(A or B).
solutionSteps: Mutually exclusive means P(A and B) = 0
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)

prompt: P(A) = 0.6. What is P(not A)?
Are the events 'drawing a heart' and 'drawing a face card' from a standard deck mutually exclusive?
solutionSteps: Can you draw a card that is both a heart AND a face card?
Yes: Jack, Queen, King of hearts
So they are NOT mutually exclusive

prompt: A card is drawn from a standard 52-card deck. What is the probability of drawing a spade?
solutionSteps: There are 4 suits in a deck

prompt: Events A and B are independent. P(A) = 0.5, P(B) = 0.3. Find P(A and B).
solutionSteps: For independent events: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B)

prompt: What type of probability is '3 out of 10 students in this class are left-handed, so P(left-handed) = 0.3'?
solutionSteps: Empirical probability is based on observed data
It's based on real observations = empirical

prompt: Two dice are rolled. What is the probability of getting a sum of 7?
What makes events A and B independent?
solutionSteps: Independent means one doesn't affect the other
Knowing B occurred doesn't change P(A)
Also: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B)

prompt: P(A) = 0.4, P(B) = 0.5, P(A and B) = 0.2. Find P(A or B).
solutionSteps: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)

prompt: Which probability value is NOT valid?
A bag contains 3 red and 5 blue marbles. Two marbles are drawn without replacement. Are these events independent or dependent?
solutionSteps: Without replacement means the first draw affects the second
After drawing one marble, probabilities change
There are fewer marbles for the second draw

prompt: Subjective probability is based on:
solutionSteps: Example: 'I think there's a 60% chance of rain'

prompt: Events A and B partition the sample space. P(A) = 0.35. What is P(B)?
solutionSteps: Partition means A and B cover everything with no overlap

prompt: Classical probability assumes:
solutionSteps: Classical probability: P = favorable outcomes / total outcomes
This assumes all outcomes are equally likely
Example: fair die, each face has P = 1/6
Used when outcomes have equal chances

prompt: A two-way table has 200 total observations. Cell (Row 1, Column 1) has 45 observations. What is the joint probability for this cell?
solutionSteps: Joint probability = cell count / grand total

prompt: In a table with row totals 80 and 120 (grand total 200), what is the marginal probability of Row 1?
solutionSteps: Marginal probability = row total / grand total

prompt: P(A) = 0.3, P(B) = 0.5, P(A and B) = 0.1. Using the addition rule, find P(A or B).
solutionSteps: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)

prompt: In a survey, 40% of people exercise. If 5 unrelated people are randomly selected, what is the probability that all 5 exercise?
30% of a population has a trait. For 4 random unrelated people, what is P(at least one has the trait)?

solutionSteps: It happens less than 5% of the time

prompt:

| | Yes | No | Total |

|Female| 25 | 25 | 50 |
|Total| 55 | 45 | 100 |

prompt: Using the same table, find P(Female OR Yes).

prompt: If 25% of people are left-handed and we select 3 unrelated people, P(exactly 0 left-handed) = ?
What distinguishes a joint probability from a marginal probability?
choices: Joint involves two conditions, marginal involves one
Marginal involves two conditions, joint involves one
correctAnswer: Joint involves two conditions, marginal involves one
solutionSteps: Joint: P(A and B) - probability of both conditions

prompt: 15% of parts are defective. In a sample of 6 random parts, what is P(none defective)?

solutionSteps: An event is unusual if P < 0.05

prompt: 60% of customers order a drink. For 3 random customers, P(all 3 order drink) = ?
